title: Doctor's college apologises decades after 'unfortunate experiment'
text:
Doctor's college apologises decades after 'unfortunate experiment' Last updated 22:01, February 13 2017 MARY FITZGERALD/FAIRFAX NZ 
The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists president Ian Page apologises at the book launch. 
Victims of National Women's 'Unfortunate Experiment' have received an apology, decades after the malpractice which contributed to multiple deaths. 
Ian Page, the president of The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, told an audience at Auckland's AUT University on Monday that the college "deeply regrets" the "human suffering" cervical cancer patients at the Auckland-based-hospital experienced. 
The college, which trains and accredits gynaecologists and obstetricians, "extended its heartfelt sympathies" to the patients and their families, Page said. The experiment, starting in 1966 at National Women's, saw the late Professor Herbert Green follow women with major cervical abnormalities without definitively treating them, and without their knowledge or consent. SUPPLIED 
Professor Herbert Green led the National Women's study conducted without consent. 
READ MORE: * Can cancers be cured? 
It is unclear how many women were part of the study, but about 70 were said to have developed cancer and as many as half died. 
The group at AUT University had gathered for the launch of Doctors in Denial: The forgotten women in the 'unfortunate experiment' by Dr Ron Jones, a junior doctor at the hospital during Professor Green's study. MARY FITZGERALD/FAIRFAX NZ 
Dr Ron Jones. A junior doctor at National Women's in the 1980s, Jones fought to expose the unethical patient study. 
Jones was involved in exposing the experiment in the 1980s. 
On Monday he thanked the people who helped him publish the book, he was conciliatory toward the families who had victims die as a result of the experiment. 
ANATOMY OF A TRAVESTY 
In 1987, outspoken women's health advocates and writers, Sandra Coney and Phillida Bunkle, published a magazine expose An Unfortunate Experiment At National Woman's. Ad Feedback 
Soon after, the Cartwright Enquiry led by judge and now Dame Silvia Cartwright confirmed Coney and Bunkle's claims dozens of women had been subjected to late or non-treatment of cervical cancer. 
In 1988 The Report of the Cervical Cancer Inquiry, also identified systemic and ethical failures by researchers at National Women's. 
No apology was ever made by health authorities. 
On Sunday Auckland District Health Board offered its own apology to the victims. 
On Monday, AUT Pro Vice Chancellor of health and environmental sciences Max Abbott said it was "appropriate the Auckland District Health Board gave an apology, albeit 30 years too late". 
Coney, who attended the book launch, said the "apology is for the victims". - Stuff
